revised_title: Impairment of Second Order Motion Perception in Patients with Unilateral Focal Brain Damage
tldr: The article investigates a patient with a unilateral focal brain lesion who has a permanent disorder in perceiving second-order motion but not first-order motion in their contralateral visual field. This finding suggests that separate pathways for motion perception exist, either as divergent pathways from area MT or even from primary visual cortex, or as separate pathways from subcortical areas to extrastriate visual areas.
